title: Frankie Bridge admits depression medication 'keeps her alive'
text:
Frankie Bridge admitted medication to treat depression keeps her alive as she discussed her battle with the mental health condition on Thursday's episode of Loose Women

The Saturdays singer, 30, who first revealed she been battling depression in 2012, said she dealt with the condition on a daily basis using therapy and medication.

She said: 'I've kind of accepted I'll always be on medication. And as far as I'm concerned it keeps me alive.

'Also, without the therapy there's only so much the medication can do.

'It's still something I deal with on a daily basis and I will do for the rest of my life.'

Also if she feels defined by the condition during her appearance on World Mental Health Day, the star said: 'I do sometimes worry that it gives people an opinion on me already before they've met me. "Maybe she's a bit miserable".'

'After I said my piece I pulled away from it, I was scared of being the poster girl for depression.'

Interview: She said: 'I've kind of accepted I'll always be on medication. And as far as I'm concerned it keeps me alive'

She added: 'It's still something I deal with on a daily basis and I will do for the rest of my life'

Frankie, who shares sons Parker, five, and Carter, four, with husband Wayne Bridge added: 'I'm still learning. At my boys' school, they did a mental health class, a couple of classes on how to look out for signs. I thought that was amazing and showed how far we've come.

'When I grew up you pushed a lot of things under the carpet and with the boys, it's something that I'm trying not to do, I'm still learning!'

The star has now written book Open Mind detailing her experience with depression, saying: 'I felt like in my position I had, I owed, not just The Saturdays fans, but people to be able to say this is how it was for me, to try and help people to not feel alone and understand it.'

'It's to help people not to feel alone, but also to help people in the way that self-help books helped me.

Discussing looking at her doctor's notes, she said: 'It was quite shocking, one, because there were things in there I don't remember, and two, there were things that I didn't realise were such a big deal for me at that time.

Support: Frankie is married to former footballer Wayne Bridge - the couple share two sons

'It just goes to show that someone with a mental illness can see the world so different.'

In 2012 Frankie revealed she had been battling depression, after she was forced to take a hiatus from the Saturdays during which she was hospitalised for treatment.

The star later said she had been suffering from depression since the age of 15, when she was in pop band S Club Juniors.

The star said having children helped her deal with the condition, even though she initially feared she would get post-natal depression.
